class_notes:
"The Event" | What is an event? And what makes something eventful as opposed to ordinary? And how do we deal with it when it changes everything about our lives? This course will explore such questions to get a handle on what an event is and how it happens through the themes of love, fate, trauma, absurdity, faith, hope, and revolution. Texts will include literary works by Franz Kafka, Flannery O'Connor, Herman Melville, and Sophocles; films by von Trier and Kieslowski; and critical pieces by Badiou, Freud, and Heidegger.
Regular discussion posts on the readings, short writing assignments, and two substantive papers.


*T SYNC, TH ASYNC
course_description: This course draws on classical, modern, and contemporary texts to introduce skills required for reading comparatively across national traditions and academic disciplines with an emphasis on close reading, critical interpretation, and the multiplicity of linguistic traditions around the world.
